title: 2022 Los Angeles mayoral election
deleted: [[Black Lives Matter]] has continually brought race relations and police brutality to the forefront of political discussion in Los Angeles. [[Mike Feuer|Feuer]] was caught up in controversy when he was involved in prosecuting Black Lives Matter activists on battery charges that many deemed to be untrue. (In the face of public outcry, Feuer's office dropped the charges.)<ref>{{Cite web |date=February 8, 2019 |title=L.A. city attorney agrees to drop charges against Black Lives Matter leader amid public outcry |url=https://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-melina-abdullah-charges-20190206-story.html |website=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> This attempted prosecution came back into the public eye in 2020, when a Black Lives Matter leader Feuer tried to prosecute—[[California State University, Los Angeles|Cal State LA]] professor [[Melina Abdullah]]—announced that she would sue the city over her wrongful arrest.<ref>{{Cite web |date=February 11, 2020 |title=L.A. Black Lives Matter leader sues city, ex-LAPD Chief Beck, alleging wrongful arrest |url=https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-02-11/black-lives-matter-leader-sues-city-ex-police-chief-beck |website=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>

Feuer's battle with Black Lives Matter occurs amidst an environment in which, critics charge, the city attorney's office has been involved in protecting violent police officers and prosecuting nonviolent African-Americans.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 20, 2015 |title=Why Angelenos Need to Pay Closer Attention to their City Attorney's Office |url=https://www.jasmyneacannick.com/why-angelenos-need-to-pay-closer-attention-to-their-city-attorneys-office/}}</ref> His heavy-handed prosecution of Patricia Beers for blocking a sidewalk drew criticism, as did his attempts to block the release of a video depicting the beating of Clinton Alford in South Los Angeles.<ref>{{Cite web |date=April 21, 2015 |title=LAPD officer charged with assault in videotaped beating |url=https://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-lapd-officer-charged-with-assault-after-videotaped-beating-20150420-story.html |website=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>

Though no current mayoral candidates were involved, the husband of [[Jackie Lacey]] pulling a gun on Black Lives Matter protesters drew attention to the controversies surrounding [[Jackie Lacey]].<ref>{{Cite web |author1=Stella Chan |author2=Cheri Mossburg |title=Los Angeles County DA's husband points gun toward Black Lives Matter protesters |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/02/us/los-angeles-county-da-jackie-lacey-husband-black-lives-matter-gun/index.html |website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Betz |first=Bradford |date=March 2, 2020 |title=Los Angeles DA apologizes after husband points gun at Black Lives Matter protesters |url=https://www.foxnews.com/us/los-angeles-da-apologizes-after-husband-points-gun-at-black-lives-matter-protesters |website=Fox News}}</ref> Lacey having been endorsed by [[Mike Feuer|Feuer]], [[Herb Wesson|Wesson]], and other potential mayoral candidates has been much discussed.<ref>{{Cite web |date=June 22, 2020 |title=Garcetti, Feuer, LA City Councilmen Urged To Withdraw Endorsements Of District Attorney Jackie Lacey |url=https://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2020/06/22/eric-garcetti-mike-feur-city-councilmen-urged-withdraw-endorsements-jackie-lacey/}}</ref>

It has been suggested that the aftermath of the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] will play a major role in the election. In early 2020, the disease became the top killer in Los Angeles. Potential frontrunner [[Mike Feuer|Feuer]] was in charge of prosecuting businesses refusing to obey the pandemic "Safer At Home" order, which gained mixed reception from medical professionals and small business owners.<ref>{{Cite web |date=April 23, 2020 |title=LA charges 29 businesses for refusing to close amid stay-at-home order |url=https://www.dailynews.com/la-charges-29-businesses-for-refusing-to-close-amid-stay-at-home-order}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=staff |first=ABC7 com |date=April 15, 2020 |title=City of Los Angeles prosecuting businesses that violate safer-at-home orders |url=https://abc7.com/6103894/ |website=ABC7 Los Angeles}}</ref> [[Rick Caruso|Caruso]], though he has yet to declare a candidacy, gave multiple media statements in regard to recovery after [[COVID-19]] that many believe are a precursor to his mayoral declaration.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Los Angeles Developer Rick Caruso Shares Vision For Coronavirus Recovery |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/los-angeles-developer-rick-caruso-shares-vision-for-coronavirus-recovery/ar-BB12XpVW |website=www.msn.com}}</ref>

The [[killing of George Floyd]] led to national and international backlash and protests. [[George Floyd protests in Los Angeles County, California|Protests swept Los Angeles]], with many protesters calling to [[defund the police]] or [[police abolition movement|abolish them]]. The actions of [[Mayor of Los Angeles|Mayor]] [[Eric Garcetti]] and [[Los Angeles Chief of Police|Chief of Police]] [[Michel Moore]] provoked significant criticism.<ref>{{Cite web |title=LAPD Chief Moore under fire over looting remarks, police treatment of protesters |url=https://news.yahoo.com/lapd-chief-moore-under-fire-120057936.html |website=news.yahoo.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Woodyard |first=Jordan Culver and Chris |title=Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore apologizes after saying George Floyd's death is on the 'hands' of looters |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/06/02/george-floyd-los-angeles-chief-michel-moore-death-looters/3127688001/ |website=USA TODAY}}</ref> The implementation of a citywide curfew was also hotly debated. Mike Feuer was originally involved in trying to prosecute protesters who violated curfew, but he later dropped this plan.<ref>{{Cite web |title=L.A. city attorney drops mandatory meetings for curfew violators |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/la-city-attorney-drops-mandatory-meetings-for-curfew-violators/ar-BB15gBHu |website=www.msn.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=LA Protesters Arrested For Violating Curfew Won't Be Charged |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/live-updates-protests-for-racial-justice/2020/06/09/872690122/l-a-protesters-arrested-for-violating-curfew-wont-be-charged |website=NPR.org}}</ref> Defunding the police or abolishing the LAPD, once a fringe political belief, has now taken center stage thanks to Black Lives Matter protests.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Richards |first=Erin |title=Defund police in schools? How the movement got momentum after George Floyd's death |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/education/2020/06/11/defund-police-school-george-floyd-death-protests/5338940002/ |website=USA TODAY}}</ref>
